(°C) Conversion (%) Selectivity (%) H2/CO (equilibrium) CO H2 Catalyst-PL (p) 550 29.3 54.2 45.8 0.84 (0.66) 600 46.5 51.5 48.5 0.94 (0.75) 650 63.8 51.5 48.5 0.94 (0.84) 700 77.6 50.2 49.8 0.99 (0.91) Catalyst-Comm (p) 550 28.7 49.0 51.0 1.04 (0.66) 600 48.5 44.4 55.6 1.25 (0.75) 650 58.6 40.6 59.4 1.46 (0.84) 700 43.8 41.2 58.8 1.42 (0.91) A novel nickel-based catalyst for methane dry reforming: A metal honeycomb-type catalyst prepared by sol–gel method and electroless plating Choji Fukuhara ⁎ Ryogo Hyodo Kazumasa Yamamoto Keigo Masuda Ryo Watanabe Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Shizuoka University, 3-5-1 Johoku, Naka-ku, Hamamatsu, Shizuoka 432-8561, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry and Biochemical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Shizuoka University 3-5-1 Johoku, Naka-ku Hamamatsu Shizuoka 432-8561 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +81 53 478 1171; fax: +81 53 476 0095. Graphical abstract A honeycomb-type nickel-based catalyst was prepared by a combination technique consisting of a sol–gel method and an electroless plating method on a stainless steel substrate. The catalyst layer formed onto the fin substrate consisted of an alumina layer and a nickel component. The alumina layer was porous and was about 7μm in thickness, and the nickel component was deposited not only on the alumina surface but also inside the pores. The nickel particles formed on the surface were 70–150nm in diameter. The prepared nickel-based honeycomb catalyst demonstrated a high performance for methane dry reforming, indicating that the catalyst degradation was quite small even under severe CO2/CH4 conditions. The amount of the deposited carbon onto the nickel-based catalyst was much smaller than that on the commercial catalyst, which was thought to be one of the factors in the reduced deterioration of this honeycomb catalyst. Furthermore, the H2/CO ratio as a synthesis gas over this nickel-based catalyst was a smaller value than that of the commercial catalyst, which is a convenient reforming property for alkane manufacturing. The deposited carbon on the nickel-based honeycomb catalyst was a whisker carbon with non-condensed state. Keywords Nickel-based catalyst Structured catalyst Methane dry reforming Electroless plating Sol–gel method 1 Introduction The dry reforming of methane is a reaction that produces a synthesis gas with a low H2/CO ratio. This reaction then has played an important role as a reaction that produces the raw material gas for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis and alcohol synthesis. Recently, the dry reforming has also attracted attention as a reaction that converts greenhouse gases (namely CH4 and CO2) into highly useful resource gases. Such attention has thus accelerated the research on catalyst and system development for the dry reforming to a greater extent. The important point in constructing the dry reforming system is to develop a catalyst inducing a strong tolerance for carbon deposition and to supply reaction energy to the reactive zone efficiently, because the reforming is a relatively high endothermic reaction (CH4 +CO2 =2CO+2H2, ΔH0 =247.0kJ/mol). Additionally, the processing of a large amount of raw material gas is required from an industrial viewpoint. The catalyst for the dry reforming that has been developed up to now is reported collectively in the review by Bradford and Vannice [1] and the review by Gao et al. [2]. Most of the catalysts were composed of nickel and precious metals supported onto Al2O3, ZrO2, SiO2 and MgO components. In those catalysts, to improve the tolerance to carbon deposition, the following factors were investigated; various combinations of metallic components and substrates [3–9], use of bimetallic and alloy components [10–13], and use of complex and perovskite oxides [14–18]. The research on the suppression of carbon deposition has been very active in the field of dry reforming catalysts. On the other hand, there is no research that focuses on the development of a reforming catalyst system which can efficiently supply thermal energy to the reforming zone and can enable mass processing of raw material gas. Such attention also includes very important points for constructing a future reforming system. In the case of converting a large amount of greenhouse gas catalytically and utilizing it effectively as a resource, development of a catalyst system that constructs the dry reforming zone with a superior heat transfer property and with a mass processing ability of the raw material is very important. The construction of a structured dry reforming system, which integrates a reactive zone and a heat-transferring zone, is an attractive reforming system for providing effective heat energy utilization and mass processing of the raw material. The structured dry reforming system could be constructed by forming a dry reforming component onto a metal substrate such as a plate-type catalyst and a metal honeycomb type catalyst [19–30]. This reaction system produces a superior heat energy utilization by conductive heat transfer and also produces a decrease in the pressure drop in the reaction zone, which would enable treating a large amount of the raw material. If a load fluctuation would occur in the operation, the system could respond rapidly. Recently, the research on the development of the structured catalyst has been activated from the viewpoint of constructing a special reaction field and process intensification. The preparation technique for the structured catalyst has been summarized in Meille's review [31]. Althought a common method of preparing a structured catalyst involves wash-coat and sol–gel techniques as described in this review, we have focused our attention on an elecroless plating for easily and uniformly depositing a catalytic component onto a metallic surface. We have then prepared a nickel-based catalyst on a honeycomb-type stainless-fin by combining the sol–gel method and an electroless plating technique [32]. We have indicated that the prepared honeycomb catalyst showed a high activity for steam reforming of methane, which is a highly endothermic reaction [32]. Moreover, we also found that this structured catalyst had a high tolerance for the carbon deposition. It was inferred that the reason for such high performance and tolerance of the prepared catalyst was an effective heat supply to the reaction zone by conductive heat transfer and also deposition of the nickel component by the electroless plating technique. Such a high heat transfer and a high carbon deposition tolerance of this nickel-based structured catalyst would produce a positive performance in the dry reforming of methane. In the present study, the methane dry reforming properties of this nickel-based honeycomb catalyst were investigated and compared with those of an industrial commercial catalyst. Some physicochemical properties of the catalyst were also investigated by SEM (scanning electron microscopy) observations and elementary analysis by XPS (X-rays photoelectron spectroscopy) and EDX (energy dispersion X-rays). As a result, the nickel-based structured catalyst showed a higher dry reforming activity than the commercial catalyst. The amount of carbon depositing onto the catalyst was considerably lower, and the catalyst degradation was also small even under a severe CO2/CH4 condition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of nickel-based honeycomb type catalyst A ferrite-type stainless steel honeycomb-fin (18mmφ ×45mm length; cell density, 100cpsi; apparent surface area, 250cm2; fin thickness, 0.1mm) was used as the metallic honeycomb substrate [32]. After washing and activating the fin surface with a 6M HCl solution, the aluminum-triisopropoxide sol (Al[OCH(CH3)2]3, 12g; HNO3 aq., 6ml; HCHO, 4ml; H2O, 80ml) was uniformly coated on the fin surface. The fin substrate was then calcined at 800°C (ramping time, 1.0h; holding time, 2.0h) to form a γ-alumina layer on its surface. Subsequently, the Pd–Sn alternate plating was performed to deposit the Pd nuclide. The fin substrate was alternately immersed 20 times in the activation liquid (PdCl2, 1.4×10−3 mol/L; HCl aq., 5.7×10−3 mol/L) and the sensitization liquid (SnCl2·2H2O, 1.1×10−3 mol/L; HCl aq., 5.7×10−3 mol/L). The nuclide was reduced with 3M hydrazine. Finally, the substrate was immersed in the nickel plating bath to deposit the nickel component onto its surface. The nickel plating bath was a sodium borohydride bath (NiCl2·6H2O, 45g/L; NaBH4, 0.6g/L; NaOH, 20g/L; NH2CH2CH2NH2, 60ml/L). The plating time was 30min, and the plating temperature was 55°C. After washing in a water bath, the prepared catalyst was dried in air at room temperature. The amount of the deposited nickel was about 22wt%. 2.2 Performance test of methane dry reforming The dry reforming of methane over the prepared catalyst was conducted at atmospheric pressure using a conventional flow reactor. After the catalyst was reduced at 600°C (ramping time, 1.0h; holding time: 1.0h) in a hydrogen stream (100ml/min), a raw material gas was fed into the reactor. The flow rate of methane was 1.0×10−3−7.0×10−3 mol/min, the ratio of carbon dioxide to methane (CO2/CH4) 1–3, the partial pressure of raw material 0.8atm (nitrogen balance), and the reaction temperature 550–700°C. The net weight of catalyst (mainly, nickel and alumina) over the fin substrate was 0.09, 0.45, 0.63g. The methane conversion was calculated from the following Eq. (1). The effluent gas from the reactor was analyzed with TCD gas chromatograph (SHIMADZU, GC-8A) (1) CH 4 conversion ( % ) = 1 − Molar ratio of methane at outlet Molar ratio of methane at inlet × 100 2.3 Characterization of the plated layer The surface morphology and a sectional view of the plated layers were observed using SEM (scanning electron microscopy, JEOL, JSM-7001F), and the elemental profiles in the same fields were analyzed using EDX (energy dispersion X-rays, AMETEK, Pegasus). The specific surface areas of the plated catalysts were measured by the BET method (BEL JAPAN, BEL-SORP) using nitrogen at its liquid temperature. The chemical forms of nickel and palladium in the plated layer were determined by XPS (X-rays photoelectron spectroscopy, SHIMADZU, ESCA3400). The binding energy was referred to the contaminant carbon (C1s =284.6eV) for convenience. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface morphology of the prepared catalyst Fig. 1 shows an overview and typical surface morphology of the prepared honeycomb catalyst after nickel-plating for 30min. From the SEM, particles of about 70–150nm in particle size were formed on the fin substrate. The lathy and jaggy boundary areas were also recognized on the surface of each particle. As predicted from such fine particles, the prepared catalyst had a relatively high specific surface area, which was confirmed by the BET value of 152m2/g. How such a particle was formed onto the fin substrate was investigated. Fig. 2 shows changes in the surface morphology and the size distribution of the deposited particles after the alternate plating of Pd–Sn, versus the plating time. Fig. 3 shows the XPS spectra of Pd3d and Ni2p in these deposits. All XPS samples were etched by argon ions (accelerating voltage, 2kV; partial pressure, 5×10−4 Pa; etching time, 30s) before the measurement. From the XPS spectrum at 0min (before the nickel plating), the particles with a size of about 20–70nm shown in Fig. 2 would be presumed to be Pd particles (334.8eV; Pd0). In the Pd–Sn alternate plating, the reaction of Pd2+ +Sn2+ →Pd0 +Sn4+ progressed, and the Pd nuclide was formed on the aluminum surface. The particle size increased as the plating time proceeded, and the particle diameter at 10min was 40–150nm. Especially, a remarkable growth of the particles was observed between 2 and 5min. In Fig. 3, the Ni2p spectrum (852.6eV; Ni0, 856.0eV; Ni2+) was confirmed at 2min of plating, and the peak intensity had strengthened as the plating time proceeded. The Pd3d spectrum was not detected after 5min though it was confirmed at 2min. These results indicated that the electron discharge by the anodic oxidation of the reducing agent causes the nickel component to be deposited onto the palladium nuclide and then the particle size increased with the plating time, which is generally proposed as the plating mechanism [33]. The particle diameter was about 45–160nm after 30min, and the lathy and jaggy boundary areas were recognized on the surface of each particle as well as that shown in Fig. 1. The Ni2p spectrum intensity was strong, meaning that the nickel component had been sufficiently deposited at this time. Fig. 4 shows a sectional view of the fin substrate and its sectional element profile measured by EDX. The elemental analysis was from the section along the white line shown in the SEM. The alumina layer was formed with good adhesion on the stainless steel substrate, and its thickness was about 7μm. The nickel component was clearly detected within the range from the surface to about a 3μm depth and was weakly detected within the range from about 3μm depth to about a 7μm depth. These results suggested that the alumina layer formed by the sol–gel method was a porous layer, and the nickel component was deposited not only on the surface but also inside the pores. The bottom layer of the particle shown in Fig. 2 was presumed to be an alumina surface from the EDX measurement. 3.2 Dry reforming property of the structured Ni-based catalyst Fig. 5 shows the dry reforming performance of the prepared honeycomb catalyst, compared with that of the commercial catalyst (METH134, Clariant Catalysts K.K, the amount of nickel is 34wt%) under the same reaction conditions and the same catalyst weight (0.45g). The commercial catalyst, which was sifted to 250–500μm diameter using a sieve and was further ground down, was coated onto the honeycomb-fin substrate by a wash-coat method with 2-butanol solvent. Hereafter, in this paper, the catalyst prepared by electroless plating is characterized as Catalyst-PL, and the commercial catalyst as Catalyst-Comm. This figure also shows the equilibrium conversion calculated in consideration of the methane dry reforming (CH4 +CO2 =2CO+2H2) and the reverse water–gas shift reaction (CO2 +H2 =CO+H2O). The reforming activity of the Catalyst-PL was almost the same as the activity of the commercial catalyst at the lower-temperature side, but the difference between both catalysts appeared with an increase in the reaction temperature. The activity of the commercial catalyst became deteriorated as the reaction time proceeded, and the degree of such deterioration was accelerated at the higher reaction temperature. On the other hand, the Catalyst-PL did not indicate deterioration in the activity at any time and showed a high reforming activity from 550°C to 700°C though the conversion is slightly lower than the equilibrium. When the reaction temperature was set at 550°C again after 160min, the activity of the Catalyst-PL was the same as the initial conversion at 40min. It was found that the prepared nickel-based catalyst has a high and stable performance even under the severe condition of CO2/CH4 =1. According to the weight difference before and after the reaction, the amount of the deposited carbon was 0.80g-C/g-cat. on the Catalyst-PL, and 3.27g-C/g-cat. on the Catalyst-Comm. The amount deposited onto the Catalyst-PL was about one-quarter of that onto the commercial catalyst. It was inferred that this property of the Catalyst-PL was one of the factors in the decreased deterioration of reforming performance. The catalytic property of the reforming site that was prepared by combining the sol–gel method and electroless plating was obviously different from that of the commercial catalyst. The difference in such a catalytic property was also reflected in the product selectivity. Table 1 shows average values of conversion, product selectivity and H2/CO, shown in Fig. 5, at each reaction temperature. From the table, the CO selectivity of the Catalyst-PL was higher than the H2 selectivity, and this tendency was more remarkable at the lower temperature side. Additionally, the H2/CO value of the Catalyst-PL was close to the equilibrium data calculated in consideration of the dry reforming and the reverse water-gas shift reaction. The result suggested a positive progression of the reverse water-gas shift reaction or a suppression of the methane decomposition over the Catalyst-PL. On the other hand, the Catalyst-Comm showed a H2/CO ratio of more than 1.0 at the lower-temperature side, namely the H2 selectivity was high. It was thought that the catalytic property of the active sites of the Catalyst-PL was different from those of the commercial catalyst. One might think that the somewhat poor reforming activity for the Catalyst-Comm was caused by depositing the catalyst component onto the fin substrate by the wash-coat method. The dry reforming properties of the Catalyst-PL and the Catalyst-Comm were then investigated with the fixed-bed type reactor. In case of the Catalyst-PL, after being flaked off from the fin substrate and formed with a compression press, the catalyst component was sifted to 250–500μm diameter and was packed in the fixed-bed type reactor. The Catalyst-Comm was also packed in the fixed-bed type reactor after sifting to 250–500μm diameter. Fig. 6 shows the dry reforming properties of both catalysts under the same reaction conditions. The catalyst prepared by electroless plating was characterized as Catalyst-PL(p), and the commercial catalyst as Catalyst-Comm(p). The packed weight of both catalysts was 90mg. Although the activity of the Catalyst-Comm(p) was comparatively stable at 550–600°C, the deterioration in its activity was remarkable from 650°C and was considerably large at 700°C. Also, the reforming test was stopped because the blockage of the reactor tube had occurred at 160min. On the other hand, the activity of the Catalyst-PL(p) was steady at each reaction temperature, and there was no degradation in its performance. When the reaction temperature was reset at 550°C again after 160min, the initial activity obtained at 40min was still maintained. The blockage of the flow path inside the fixed-bed reactor hardly occurred in the case of the nickel-based catalyst prepared by the sol–gel method and electroless plating. In fact, the amount of the deposited carbon, which was estimated by the weight difference before and after the reaction, was 0.43g-C/g-cat. on the Catalyst-PL(p), and 2.42g-C/g-cat. on the Catalyst-Comm(p). It was thought that the preparation method combining the oxide layer formation by the sol–gel method with the metallic component deposition by electroless plating produces a high tolerance for carbon deposition for the catalyst whose active site is the nickel component. The average of conversion, the product selectivity and H2/CO ratio at each temperature shown in Fig. 6 are summarized in Table 2 . The H2/CO ratio of the Catalyst-PL(p) was 1.0 or less, which was near the equilibrium composition, as well as the Catalyst-PL. On the other hand, the H2/CO ratio of the Catalyst-Comm(p) was larger than 1.0 and was far from the equilibrium ratio. Such a difference between the equilibrium value and the experimental value was remarkable at 650°C and 700°C especially. At these temperatures, a side reaction like carbon deposition might progress considerably. 3.3 Dry reforming mechanism over the Ni-based catalyst The difference in the product selectivity between the Catalyst-PL and the Catalyst-Comm shown in Tables 1 and 2 will be discussed in this section. The popular reaction mechanism for the dry reforming of methane is the following reaction sequence proposed by Bodrov and Apel’baum [34,35] to describe the results of dry reforming over a nickel foil catalyst. (2) CH4 +∗→CH2∗+H2 (3) CO2 +∗⇌CO+O∗ (4) O∗ + H2 ⇌H2O+∗ (5) CH2∗+H2O⇌CO∗+2H2 (6) CO∗⇌CO+∗ In these reactions, some of which are not elementary, * denotes an active site on the catalyst surface, → a slower irreversible reaction, and ⇌ a quasi-equilibated reaction. First, CH4 is dissociatively adsorbed at an active site in a rate-determining step to yield the CH2 species. Subsequently, CO2 is converted to H2O by the reverse water-gas shift reaction. Finally, H2O reacts with the CH2 species to produce H2 and CO. Erdöhelyi [3,36] and Rostrup-Nielsen [37] have proposed a slight modification of the above mechanism. That is, the dissociative adsorption of Eq. (2) was modified as Eqs. (7) and (8), the reverse water-gas shift reaction was modified as Eqs. (9) and (10), and Eqs. (5) and (6) were modified as Eqs. (11) and (12). (7) CH4 +2∗→CH3∗+H∗ (8) CH3∗+(3− x)∗⇌CH x ∗+(3− x)H∗ (9) CH2 +H∗⇌CO+HO∗ (10) 2HO∗⇌H2O+O∗+∗ (11) CH x ∗+O∗+(x −2)∗⇌CO+ xH∗ (12) 2H∗⇌H2 +2∗ In each mechanism, CH4 undergoes the dissociative adsorption on the metal catalyst and is converted into CH2* and CH x *, and CO2 is converted into CO, H2O or O* by the reverse water-gas shift reaction or by the reaction with H*. As shown in Tables 1 and 2, the H2/CO ratio of the Catalyst-PL being close to the equilibrium ratio, which was calculated in consideration of the dry reforming and the reverse water-gas shift reaction, suggested that this catalyst has a high tolerance for carbon deposition even under the severe condition of CO2/CH4 =1 and that the dry reforming of methane and the reverse water-gas shift reaction mainly progress over this catalyst. On the other hand, the H2/CO ratio of the Catalyst-Comm that was larger than 1.0 suggested that CH2* and CH x * further decomposed over this catalyst and that the carbon deposition and the hydrogen generation preferentially proceeded, and also that the speed of the reverse water-gas shift reaction was slow and little formation of CO occurred due to the shortage of generated H2O and/or O*. Furthermore, the simultaneous reaction of CO disproportionation would also be considered. 3.4 Effect of reaction condition on dry reforming property Fig. 7 shows the effect of the feed rate change of the raw material on the reforming property of the Catalyst-PL. This figure also shows the CO selectivity and H2/CO ratio. At the feed rate of 1.0×10−3−3.0×10−3 mol/min, the Catalyst-PL showed almost equilibrium conversion. At 5.0×10−3 mol/min or more, its performance slightly declined, but its conversion was not far from the equilibrium. Under the feeding condition of 5.0×10−3 mol/min, the linear velocity of the raw material was 52mm/s at 500°C and 65mm/s at 700°C. Because the length of the structured catalyst was 45mm, the residence time of the reactant gas in the catalyst zone was about 0.8s or less. The S.V. based on the net volume of the catalyst layer was 201,000h−1. The prepared honeycomb catalyst would have a rapid transforming ability for the dry reforming even under the severe reforming condition. The cell density of the honeycomb substrate used in this study was 100cpsi, and it is possible to process it to a higher density cell by mechanical modification. Namely, an increase in the amount of catalyst per unit volume can be facilitated. Such densification of the cell density of the honeycomb substrate would produce an additional high catalytic performance. The tendency of CO selectivity and H2/CO ratio relative to the change in the feed rate showed that the CO generation was promptly advanced on the Catalyst-PL as well as the results shown in Tables 1 and 2. Furthermore, the amount of the deposited carbon was also little. Fig. 8 shows the effect of the CO2/CH4 ratio change in the raw material on the dry reforming property of the Catalyst-PL. At each reaction temperature, the increment in the CO2/CH4 ratio produced great improvement in the dry reforming activity. It was thought that, in the dry reforming mechanism shown in Section 3.3, the increment in the amount of CO2 in the raw material accelerates Eq. (5) by the promotion of generated H2O in Eq. (4) and causes the acceleration of Eq. (11) by the promotion of generated O* in Eq. (10). The increment in CO2 also leads to an increment in the amount of CO generation and decreases the H2/CO ratio consequentially as shown by Eq. (3) and/or Eq. (9). This result is convenient in alkane production from the synthesis gas. That is, the alkane production from the synthesis gas is generally expressed by Eq. (13). If the water-gas shift reaction occurs simultaneously, the overall reaction stoichiometry for the production of alkanes is Eq. (15). (13) nCO+(2n +1)H2 →C n H2n+2 + nH2O (14) CO+H2O→CO2 +H2 (15) 2nCO+(n +1)H2 →C n H2n+2 + nCO2 In the production of synthesis gas by the steam reforming including the water-gas shift reaction, the H2/CO ratio is usually from 3 to 4. However, the value of (2n +1)/n in Eq. (13) is from 2 to 3, and that of (n +1)/2n in Eq. (15) is less than or equal to unity. If longer-chain alkanes would be produced, the smaller value of H2/CO ratio in the synthesis gas is required because the values of (2n +1)/n and (n +1)/2n are small in the long-chain alkanes. The Catalyst-PL prepared in this study can produce such a smaller H2/CO ratio synthesis gas by adjusting the CO2/CH4 ratio in the raw material. The data in Fig. 8 suggest that the prepared Catalyst-PL has a convenient reforming property in the synthesis gas production for alkane manufacturing. It is thought that a side reaction such as methane decomposition, which produces hydrogen and carbon, does not occur easily on this catalyst and thus a low H2/CO ratio is produced. Of course, the progression of the reverse water–gas shift reaction would also be considered. In the alcohol synthesis process, because the synthesis gas with a smaller H2/CO ratio is also desired, the Catalyst-PL has a convenient advantage. 3.5 Durability performance of the structured Ni-based catalyst The Catalyst-PL prepared by the sol–gel and electroless plating techniques showed a stable property for the dry reforming as shown in Figs. 5 and 6. It also appeared that, from the weight difference before and after the reaction, the amount of deposited carbon onto this catalyst was very low. Such results forecast a long life for this catalyst. The durability performance of the Catalyst-PL was then investigated. Fig. 9 shows the results of the durability performance test for the Catalyst-PL with a structured shape, including CO selectivity and H2/CO ratio. For comparison, the CH4 conversion for the Catalyst-Comm(p) is also shown in this figure. For the Catalyst-Comm(p), a fixed-bed type reactor was adopted, and the catalyst was sufficiently diluted with quartz sand to prevent blockading of the reaction field. The CO2/CH4 ratio was 2, and the reaction temperature was 700°C. On the commercial catalyst, deterioration in the activity was seen from the start of the reaction, and an activity decrease of about 20% was observed at 30h. On the other hand, a remarkable decrease in reforming activity on the Catalyst-PL was hardly seen, and the activity of 90% or more was maintained at 30h. The H2/CO ratio was steady at around 0.8. Although the length of the durability test was only 30h, it is thought that the low amount of deposited carbon on the Catalyst-PL was reflected in the tendency of the activity to degrade only slightly. Fig. 10 shows typical SEM photographs of the surfaces of the Catalyst-PL and the Catalyst-Comm(p) after the durability performance test. A deposited carbon like whisker was observed on the surface of both catalysts, but the formation of these whiskers was different. That is, the deposited carbon on the Catalyst-PL was a whisker with non-condensed state, though that on the catalyst-Comm(p) was a condensed whisker. The whisker carbon formed on both catalysts apparently grew by tip-growth type. It is thought that the deposition of a non-condensed whisker carbon on the Catalyst-PL is one of the factors in producing the stable performance of this catalyst in the durability test. However, the deciding factor is still uncertain. It was elucidated that the amount of the deposited carbon on the honeycomb type nickel-based catalyst was less than that on the commercial catalyst. This property can be improved further. Namely, the electroless plating can deposit various kinds of a metallic component by changing the metal ion species in the plating solution, which means the possibility of depositing elemental Pd, Co and Ce having a tolerance for carbon deposition. Details on such a catalyst will be investigated in subsequent papers. 4 Conclusions Using the combination technique of the sol–gel method and the electroless plating, a nickel-based honeycomb catalyst was prepared on a stainless steel substrate. The formed catalyst layer consisted of the nickel component and the alumina layer, which was a porous body of 7μm thickness. The prepared nickel-based catalyst demonstrated a higher performance in methane dry reforming than the commercial catalyst. The performance degradation of this catalyst was quite small even under severe CO2/CH4 condition. The amount of the deposited carbon onto this nickel-based catalyst was smaller than that onto the commercial catalyst, which was thought to be one of the factors in the reduced deterioration of this catalyst. The H2/CO ratio as a synthesis gas over this nickel-based catalyst was a smaller value than that of the commercial catalyst. The deposited carbon on this nickel-based catalyst was a whisker carbon with non-condensed state. References [1] M.C.J. Bradfort M.A. Vannice Catal. Rev.: Sci. Eng. 41 1999 1 42 [2] J. Gao Z. Hou H. coredata.dc:description: A honeycomb-type nickel-based catalyst was prepared by a combination technique consisting of a sol–gel method and an electroless plating method on a stainless steel substrate. The catalyst layer formed onto the fin substrate consisted of an alumina layer and a nickel component. The alumina layer was porous and was about 7μm in thickness, and the nickel component was deposited not only on the alumina surface but also inside the pores. The nickel particles formed on the surface were 70–150nm in diameter. The prepared nickel-based honeycomb catalyst demonstrated a high performance for methane dry reforming, indicating that the catalyst degradation was quite small even under severe CO2/CH4 conditions. The amount of the deposited carbon onto the nickel-based catalyst was much smaller than that on the commercial catalyst, which was thought to be one of the factors in the reduced deterioration of this honeycomb catalyst. Furthermore, the H2/CO ratio as a synthesis gas over this nickel-based catalyst was a smaller value than that of the commercial catalyst, which is a convenient reforming property for alkane manufacturing. The deposited carbon on the nickel-based honeycomb catalyst was a whisker carbon with non-condensed state.
coredata.dc:title: A novel nickel-based catalyst for methane dry reforming: A metal honeycomb-type catalyst prepared by sol–gel method and electroless plating
